ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Shock Disorder
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of acute high-intensity acoustic incident followed by immediate otalgia, worsening tinnitus, and hyperacusis.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Documented permanent threshold shift (10-20 dB) in the right ear at high frequencies following the acoustic trauma.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Tonic Tensor Tympani Syndrome
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Proposed mechanism for the cluster of symptoms including pain, anxiety, tinnitus, and sound intolerance.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Baseline assessment from 4 years prior to establish pre-exposure hearing levels.
Assess current hearing thresholds to quantify any shift following the acoustic incident.
Evaluate middle ear and retrocochlear function.
Quantify the severity of tinnitus distress and sound intolerance (TFI, THI).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with bilateral sloping mild-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss. Comparison with historical records confirms a threshold shift in the right ear following the acoustic shock. Self-report measures indicate severe tinnitus distress and significant sound intolerance.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral sloping mild-to-severe SNHL. Right ear shows worsening of 10-20 dB HL at 3, 4, 6, and 8 kHz compared to baseline.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry (Historical)
tests.result_summary: Baseline thresholds from 4 years prior, showing better hearing in the right ear at high frequencies.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Reflexes present ipsilaterally; Right contralateral reflexes absent at 1000 and 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Self-report scales
tests.result_summary: TFI 86/100 (severe); THI 70/100 (severe); Tinnitus Severity 9/10; Sound Intolerance 9/10.

proposed_items: Hearing aids with rudimentary tinnitus masking options
counseling_actions: Validate that the ear pain is real and consistent with Acoustic Shock Disorder / Tonic Tensor Tympani Syndrome
Explain the connection between the traumatic event, emotional reaction, and physical symptoms
Advise on minimizing sound avoidance and the importance of not over-protecting hearing
Discuss the role of anxiety and depression in symptom maintenance

escalation.rationale_short: Patient diagnosed with depression and anxiety subsequent to the event; high distress warrants psychological management.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor tinnitus distress, sound tolerance, and benefit from hearing aids/masking.

expected_outcome: Tinnitus Functional Index (TFI): Score decreased from 86/100 to 57/100, a clinically significant improvement.
Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI): Score decreased from 70/100 to 44/100, a clinically significant improvement.
Subjective report: Patient reported that many environmental sounds remained too loud and pain was still produced by high-pitched sounds, horns, and sirens.
Self-management: Patient learned to navigate environmental exposures and maintain sound enrichment while avoiding setbacks.
